description.narrative: 1. # health workers in frontline services for COVID-19 response received incentive 2. # medicines and health equipment procured by UNDP

comment.narrative: 1. Unclear delivery mechanism in place to ensure effective and accurate delivery of incentive for health worker 2. The Ministry of Health is experiencing insufficiency of PPE, health equipment and medicines for disease prevention measures to be distributed to the referral health facilities
1. At least, one incentive scheme developed and operational within the ministry 2. 3 ventilators and requested PPE procured for Ministry of Health

To help ease the burden placed on the health care system, UNDP, in partnership with WHO and IOM, donated 45 ventilators to MoH for use by 18 designated referral hospitals through NDMA. 500,000 medical masks distributed to MoFA and NDMA which was supported by China Soong Ching Ling Foundation and facilitated by UNDP China and 30 additional ventilators are currently procured in 2020. In 2020, UNDP provided support for the management of medical waste through the donation of 4 incinerators for government laboratories and 4 autoclaves for referral hospitals, including installation and training for medical waste management officers.
UNDP also has provided technical support to MoH in strengthening protection for health workers on the front line; provided a collaborative framework for telemedicine, and for the development of policies, protocols, and the expansion of a vaccine supply chain monitoring system into a logistics system during the COVID-19 pandemic.
These contribution has been notable to remark UNDP contribution to response the situation of COVID19, in especially in early outbreaks.

description.narrative: (1) 1,000 refugees and host communities’ households are trained in environmental management practices (Water and environment plan intervention 2.4.5 – training and sensitisation session at household level) (2) 1,000 refugees and host communities individuals (60% women) have engaged in environmentally friendly livelihood activities (Water and environment plan intervention 2.4.5 – training and sensitisation session at household level) (3) Two milestones from the CRRF action plan are successfully delivered i.e a) the finalisation and launch of a job and livelihood plan for refugee and host communities and b) the undertaking of a local authority capacity gap assessment towards the streamlining of capacity strengthening initiative (4) One priority intervention identified within the CRRF Water and environment planned is implemented in Lamwo district (5) Number of local government authorities trained on integrating the CRRF agenda into local governance structure and processes (A minimum of 50 LGs)

3.1.2.1: Number of government entities supported to ensure business continuity and provision of basic and social services during the COVID-19 pandemic a) National government entities b) Sub-national government entities
2.3.2.2: Whether the country has measures in place to address gender-based violence (GBV) during the COVID-19 pandemic, which a) integrate violence prevention and response into COVID-19 response plans b) raise awareness through advocacy and campaigns, with targeted messages to both women and men c) provide options for women to report abuse and seek help without alerting perpetrators d) ensure continued functioning of shelters for victims of violence and expand their capacity e) ensure access to justice build capacity of key services to prevent impunity of perpetrators and protect women and their children

comment.narrative:
a) 2 (Q3= 1 Q4 = 1) (Description: - Technical assistance provided to NDMA for finance, procurement and logistics - Technical experts engaged with Federal Ministry of Health to support communication, data analysis and public health research)
b) 7 (Q3= 4 Q4 = 3) (Description: - Established a human rights task force with the Federal Ministry of Human Rights to ensure a rights-based approach to relief and recovery efforts from COVID-19. The task force developed a detailed strategy with short, medium and long term targets and recommendations to not only ensure inclusive COVID-19 recovery, but also better preparedness against other disasters in Pakistan - 5 virtual courts established in Khber Pakhtunkhwa and Merged Areas - 2 zoom licenses provided to Khyber Pakhtunkhwa Police, 1 to Khyber Pakhtunkhwa Bar Council and 1 to Peshawar High Court to ensure business continuity. - Tehsil Municipal Administrations (TMAs) with the support of Local Government Ambassadors (LGAs) in various districts and tehsil sub-divisions conducted disinfection activities, distributed sanitization supplies and conducted awareness raising sessions. - Strengthened the capcity of five Depty Commissioner (DC) offices (North Waziristan, South Waziristan, Khyber, Kurram, and Orakzai districts) of Khyber Pakhtunkhwa government through provision of IT and Communication equipment for business continuity.)

comment.narrative: - 10 PSAs developed - 1 website created - 1 animation produced - 10 graphics designed

1. Recorded songs with popular band Fansan and with 6 of Somalia’s leading singers, reaching more than 2m on social media and featuring in interviews with Universal TV, VoA and popular blogging/music video/news sites; created a comedy series with popular comedians; commissioned posters, posters and social media products from Somalia’s most famous cartoonist; and commissioned Somali poetry for distribution online and via radio broadcasts. 2. Recorded dedicated shows, including with Universal TV, Kala Maan radio, Danan radio and a programme with UNSOM syndicated to 10 radio stations across Somalia. In collaboration with the Rule of Law unit, designed posters and a handbook for awareness raising among the Somali police. 3. Supported design of posters for distribution in Puntland, Somaliland and IDP camps in multiple locations via partners in the environment portfolio, NADFOR, JPLG and IOM

description.narrative: UNDP COVID-19 Rapid Response Facility Resources. Ensure social stability in the country. Conduct analysis of direct socio-economic impact of the crisis and its spillover effects on the most vulnerable groups of Kazakhstan population.
capital of a political entity

sector.narrative: Eradicate poverty in all its forms and dimensions

description.narrative: A rapid assessment of the COIVID-crisis impact on the most vulnerable to help the Government recalibrate support measures accordingly

comment.narrative: No analysis has been done to date on direct socio-economic impact of the COVID-crisis and its spillover effects on the most vulnerable groups of Kazakhstan population

1) Development of questionnaires for various categories of the population. Identification of target groups. 2) Conducting a nationwide survey of 12,000 respondents through the Talap mobile app, upgraded for visually impaired people. 3) Data analysis, development of anti-crisis package of offers and services, presentation of the results to the key stakeholders. 4) Development of a recovery strategy and action plan informed by the results of the following two components.

1) For technical implementation, UNDP has partnered with a national think tank “TALAP” that has a deep understanding of the development context and the current situation. “TALAP” spearheaded the development of the questionnaires, with the key stakeholders from the UN agencies and the government providing their input on the questionnaire content. The key target groups covered were: SMEs and self-employed, population, including vulnerable social groups, namely the economically active population, elderly and/or single people, persons with disabilities, disadvantaged and other vulnerable categories, parents with children under 6 years of age, as well as the key stakeholders in education and healthcare. 2) The overall sample amounted to 12,067 participants across all 14 regions and 3 key cities of the country. The survey was conducted from 5 May to 10 June 2020. 3) According to the SEIA, a deterioration of the financial situation caused by quarantine measures is noted by 51% of the unemployed, 45% of low-income people, 42% of persons with disabilities, 36% of the economically active population. Quarantine measures and the state of emergency heavily impacted the most vulnerable groups of the population, as demonstrated by the indirect indicators: 40% of the unemployed and 38% of low income people reported that they could not afford enough food; 43% of the unemployed and low income people reported difficulties paying for utilities; 38% of the unemployed and 47% of low income people had to borrow money and/or take loans to pay for staple commodities. Covid-19 is devastating small businesses, currently employing 3.3 mln. people. 69.6% of SMEs were forced to suspend their economic activities and another 2.2% completely stopped operating during the quarantine. Self-employed people suffered even more, with 71% suspending their activities due to the introduction of quarantine measures. Women-entrepreneurs were more affected by quarantine measures and the state of emergency than men: during the period of quarantine, 69% of women-owned SMEs stopped their activities, compared with 59% of men-entrepreneurs. The results of the SEIA were presented to the Ministry of Labour and Social Protection, and other stakeholders including IFIs. 4) The United Nations Country Team (UNCT) developed Kazakhstan´s COVID-19 Socio-Economic Response & Recovery Plan, guided by the global UN Framework for the Immediate Socio-economic Response to COVID-19´s five pillars, the UN Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework (2021-2025), the Common Country Analysis, the Socio-Economic Impact Assessment (SEIA), as well as the wider regional Framework on Socio-Economic Response to COVID-19.

sector.narrative: Eradicate poverty in all its forms and dimensions

description.narrative: 1. Number of provinces with at least one functional SDG platform by December 2020 2. # of sub-national governments prepared and implementing SDG based period plan with UNDP support by March 2021 3. # of sub-national governments developed and piloted SDG Report Card for SDG monitoring by March 2021 4. Number of crisis-affected most vulnerable people (men and women, migrants, seasonal workers, people with disabilities) supported through selected socio-economic activities to restore their livelihoods by March 2021 5. Number of sub-national government supported with basic infrastructure and logistics for timely response to Covid-19 outbreak by June 2020 6. Number of government officials trained on crisis management, effective communication and community resilience by June 2020 7. Number of joint projects formulated with funding commitments from the private sector, government, UN agencies and other partners. 8. Revised Resource Mobilization strategy in place

comment.narrative: - Three Provinces have finalized the SDG platform Themes and potential organization (Province 2 on Resilient Cities-Extraction of Natural Resources, Gandaki Province- Green Finance and Karnalai Province- Food Security) are finalized - 11 local governments prepared the periodic plan and start implementing - UNDP has developed and rolled out a dedicated socio-economic and livelihood recovery package. The package program aims to increase the basic income of vulnerable groups by promoting local resource-based enterprises- on farm based and off farmed. - 12,386 households were directly benefitted from socio-economic recovery interventions to improve their income and livelihood - 18 socio-economic recovery project in partnerships with municipalities implemented.
- Three SDG platforms established in 2020 will be functional

description.narrative: Recovering Back Better and Strengthening Resilience for the Most Vulnerable COVID-19-Affected Rural Communities
first-order administrative division

sector.narrative: Build resilience to shocks and crisis

description.narrative: At least 4-6 counties supported to recover back better and strengthen resilience for COVID-19

comment.narrative: N/A
At least 4-6 counties supported to recover back better and strengthen resilience for COVID-19

5 counties supported to recover back better and strengthen resilience for COVID-19 First, the CO supported China's emergency response and recovery by focusing on vulnerable populations. This included saving lives of COVID-19 patients who were critically ill and front-line responders, through the provision of medical equipment (584,374 USD of clinical electrocardiogram monitors, infusion pumps, 10,000 sets of protective clothing). Second, the CO provided technical leadership on the UN socio-economic impact assessment, which provides insights on effective policy prescriptions, particularly that with a focus on the pandemic's impact on the most vulnerable. Drawing from the assessment findings sampling 5044 individuals in 1,183 households, UNDP utilized the TRAC resources in 5 counties across 5 provinces in China for recovery support. Third, the CO implemented activities to help the most vulnerable population to build back better. Urgent livelihood needs of 400 vulnerable households (1,600 villagers) in Zhangwan (Hubei) were addressed due to UNDP's support on live streaming for e-commerce. Local farmers attracted 2.1 million customers through the livestreaming and increased their sales. Challenges in managing information and finance for local businesses were addressed as UNDP set up an information management platform, currently used by 8 businesses. Fourth, the CO enhanced local public health and other basic social services, including education, in Neixiang (Henan), Zhouqu (Gansu) and Yilong (Sichuan), during the COVID and to prepare for future pandemics. 85000 students in Neixiang gained access to psychological support and received better education, as UNDP trained 960 teachers across the county on psychological support and communications. 680 patients (392 are female) in 19 villages directly benefited from the medical equipment donated by UNDP in Zhouqu; 40 doctors and nurses were fully trained to use the donated respiratory machine; 10 clinical electrocardiogram monitors and 50 first-aid kits. In Yilong, 10 villages received PPE and doctors and nurses in 5 hospitals were trained on epidemiology investigation and monitoring. Also, UNDP helped Yilong establish a long-term collaborative network with West China Hospital of Sichuan University to receive continuous technical support and guidance for pandemic control. Additionally, education recovery plans were developed in communities in Chengbu (Hunan) focusing on LNOB. 1,920 teachers have enhanced capacity on online education as UNDP mapped out the local education improvement needs and provided 8 training courses. The 2020 TRAC (175,000 USD) managed to leverage and mobilize another 1,005,046.50 USD to directly benefit 4 additional counties in 4 other provinces, in addition the Zhangwan District of Shiyan City in Hubei, the epicenter of the COVID-19 in 2020, as proposed in the application document.
project closure

capital of a political entity

Ampliar capacidades para fortalecer el diagnóstico molecular de la COVID-19, en laboratorios de La Habana y laboratorios regionales, ubicados en Villa Clara y Santiago de Cuba. Así como fortalecer la captura, procesamiento de datos y gestión de información en las Salas Situacionales del Ministerio de Salud Pública y del Estado Mayor Nacional de la Defensa Civil (EMNDC). Además del fortalecimiento del control de infecciones en centros de atención a pacientes sospechosos o confirmados de padecer la COVID-19.
capital of a political entity

sector.narrative: Build resilience to shocks and crisis

description.narrative: 1- Number of national updates on the COVID-19 that include information on the molecular tests performed. 2- Number of national and local institutions with infraestructure and operational capacities strengthened to assure their efficient and effective performance in the face of COVID-19 3- Number of new audiovisual and printed promotional material produced

comment.narrative: 1. 90 actualizaciones realizadas 2. 12 instituciones nacionales y locales fortalecidas 3. 8 productos comunicativos realizados

1. Desde marzo de 2020, el gobierno cubano y el Ministerio de Salud Pública, establecieron mecanismos para informar a la población la evolución de la enfermedad y alertar sobre la protección ante su incidencia en el país. Una vía es la habitual Conferencia de prensa que diariamente se transmite por los canales de la televisión nacional y otras redes de comunicación. Al frente de esta Conferencia de prensa está el Dr. Francisco Duran García, director nacional de Epidemiología del MINSAP. Cada día se muestra información relevante relacionada con la recolección, análisis e interpretación de datos, que permite explicar a la población, de forma concisa, la evolución de la enfermedad. A través de gráficos, tablas y mapas se presenta esta información y se interpreta detalladamente cada dato expuesto. Con el fortalecimiento de la Sala Situacional del MINSAP, se pudo generar información para los partes diarios de actualización transmitidos por las cadenas nacionales de radio y televisión. A partir de agosto y hasta octubre de 2020, la información recogida en los partes incluía la utilización de los suministros médicos con que apoyó el proyecto, así como su impacto en los resultados alcanzados. Se realizaron 90 partes en 3 meses, con esta información. 2. Se fortalecieron 12 instituciones nacionales: Instituto de Medicina Tropical Pedro Kouri-IPK, 5 Laboratorios de Diagnóstico de La Habana de los Hospitales Hermanos Ameijeiras, Manuel Fajardo, Fructoso Rodríguez, Centro de Higiene, Epidemiología y Microbiología de La Habana y el Laboratorio de la Defensa Civil. Los hospitales clínico-quirúrgicos Miguel Enríquez, en La Habana y los hospitales provinciales clínico-quirúrgicos Arnaldo Milián Castro, en Villa Clara y Saturnino Lora, en Santiago de Cuba. La Sala Situacional del MINSAP y Prosalud. En la Sala Situacional del Ministerio de Salud Pública, apoyada con equipamiento informático, se pudieron manejar, de manera efectiva, informaciones clave para la entrega de datos y pronósticos esenciales a las autoridades sanitarias y de gobierno competentes; para la toma de decisiones. Se transmitió información relevante relacionada con la recolección, análisis e interpretación de datos, que permitió explicar a la población, de forma concisa, la evolución de la enfermedad, por los canales de la televisión nacional y otras redes de comunicación en Cuba. Se pudieron realizar video-conferencias, con las provincias y varias instituciones involucradas, facilitando una mejor organización del trabajo. Se adquirieron 3 equipos de ultrasonido o ecógrafos para vigilancia y diagnóstico de pacientes con comorbilidades y sospechosos de COVID. Se ubicaron en hospitales clínicos-quirúrgicos de La Habana, Villa Cara y Santiago de Cuba. Estos resultados y los gastos asociados a ellos, se complementaron con los fondos TRAC y fondos programáticos de PNUD. Se fortaleció el control de infecciones en centros de atención a pacientes sospechosos o confirmados de padecer la COVID-19, con: 59 Kits de diagnósticos para PCR-TR, 4,000 medios de transporte para virus Puritam UniTrans-RT (UT-362) y 2,640 QIAam viral RNA minikit 240. Se realizaron 5,546 pruebas de diagnóstico por infección por SARS CoV-2 , exudados nasofaríngeos PCR-TR a 4,000 personas y extracciones de ácido nucléico viral a 2,640 personas. Se cubrió a más de 12,000 personas con estos insumos médicos.
Se proporcionaron medios de protección personal (EPP) y suministros en apoyo a la ampliación de las capacidades de admisión hospitalaria que garantizó la vitalidad de los servicios y el apoyo al personal clave del MINSAP y de la Defensa Civil, consistentes en: 40,000 guantes, 7,000 bolsas para desechos biológicos, 950 batas quirúrgicas, 8,352 mascarillas N-95 y 20,000 mascarillas IIR. Estos artículos fueron destinados al Instituto de Medicina Tropical Pedro Kouri-IPK y para 5 Laboratorios de Diagnóstico de hospitales La Habana y para el Laboratorio de la Defensa Civil. Estos resultados y los gastos asociados a ellos, se complementaron con los fondos TRAC y fondos programáticos de PNUD. Se beneficiaron 41,000 trabajadores de Salud Pública. 3. Se ampliaron las capacidades para implementar campañas de capacitación y sensibilización con perspectiva de género, alineadas con la campaña nacional del MINSAP de prevención y reducción del riesgo de contagio por COVID-19, con: -10 productos comunicativos: conjunto de postales, sueltos, spot publicitarios, concurso “Quédate en casa, quédate en igualdad”. Todos los materiales tuvieron en cuenta las consideraciones de género. Estos resultados y los gastos asociados a ellos, se complementaron con los fondos TRAC y fondos programáticos de PNUD, hasta completar y superar el indicador de 10 productos comunicativos. Se realizó una amplia cobertura por los medios de comunicación nacional. Particularmente en redes sociales, con un alcance de más de 55 000 personas.

comment.narrative: 3.1: -Water tanks and soap at 14 locations & 2 tanks for Somaliland -Water tanks and soap at 3 locations & 2 tanks for Puntland -Pipes for 18 prison locations in Puntland & Somaliland 3.2: -Water tanks and soap at 23 sites -Pipes for 23 locations -Water tanks for 4 police stations in Puntland -Zoom training for the Community policing directorate on health and hygiene, as well as on prevention and mitigation of stigma and discrimination, equipping the police to work in the crisis situation. -Efforts made through the community policing directorate to disseminate UN ICT materials on health and hygiene to the local police commanders. 3.3: -Develop radio programmes -Develop guidance note for community leaders -Somalia Storytellers to integrate messages in advocacy clips -Psychosocial counselling units to support COVID and SGBV related work.

1-An implementation plan has been developed with SPF and MOIS to roll out community policing at 3 districts in Mogadishu. 2-The Concept Note is finalized on implementation plan with PHRDO to undertake prison monitoring across Puntland. 3-CSO’s will be trained to provide human rights monitoring reports.

1. Volunteer burial teams set up and functional in FMSs 2. 30 religious leaders have been engaged in Jubaland, Puntland, HirShabelle and Galmudug to take the awareness campaign forward in four selected key locations per state. 3. 200.000 flyers providing healthcare messages combined with religious guidance as well as 34.500 face masks are being disseminated by the religious leaders, providing life saving information to the people in their communities.
